awd_titl_txt: Conference: CAS-Climate: Materials Chemistry in Electrochemical Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The Division of Chemistry is sponsoring this workshop entitled "CAS-Climate: Materials Chemistry in Electrochemical Energy Storage" to be held on September 26-30, 2022 at the Telluride Science Research Center (TSRC), Telluride, Colorado.  Battery technologies play a leading role in harnessing renewable energy and combating global warming and environmental challenges caused by current dependence on fossil fuel.   In the meantime, rapidly increasing energy storage demands for consumer electronics, electric vehicles, electrical grids, and clean energy storage raise the level of urgency for the development of advanced rechargeable batteries with superior energy storage performance compared to the state-of-the-art lithium ion batteries.  This workshop will focus on the mechanistic understanding and exploration of materials chemistry in electrochemical energy storage, including in lithium ion batteries, multivalent batteries, and redox flow batteries. This workshop aims to gather established leaders and emerging investigators to exchange novel ideas and address materials challenges in energy storage science.

Professor Tianbiao Liu from the Chemistry Department of Utah State University is organizing this workshop.  There are five sub-topics: (i)  lithium ion and lithium metal batteries, (ii) beyond lithium ion batteries, (iii) electrolyte and interfacial chemistry, (iv) batteries for scalable energy storage, and (v) advanced characterization and computational modeling.  Through these discussions, the workshop participants will share knowledge and exchange perspectives on the challenges and opportunities for chemistry in the field of electrochemical energy storage. The outcomes of the workshop will be disseminated to the scientific community via a workshop report.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF workshop was held at the Telluride Science Research Center (TSRC) in Telluride, Colorado, from September 26 to September 30, 2022. A full list of invited speakers is provided in the Appendix. In total, the workshop included 22 in-person participants (Figure 1) and 5 virtual participants. A diverse and dynamic group of participants attended the workshop, representing academia, national laboratories, and spanning various career demographics. The workshop emphasized diversity and inclusion by involving underrepresented scientists, female scientists, and international principal investigators. Geographic and institutional diversity were also considered, as invitations were limited to one or two per organization. 

The workshop created a high-level platform for a select number of attendees to exchange unpublished work and original concepts, sparking new ideas and new solutions to promote extensive collaborations in the future. The NSF workshop consisted of five in-person and one virtual session over four meeting days. Each session was followed by a 30 minute discussion to highlight the opportunities and challenges of each topic. Specifically, the workshop held in-depth presentations and discussions on mechanistic understanding and exploration of materials chemistry in electrochemical energy storage, including, redox flow batteries, Li ion and Li metal batteries, cathode materials, and multi-valent batteries. Intellectual presentations and discussions advanced our knowledge in battery materials chemistry. New materials and energy storage technologies inspired by the workshop will promote the use of clean energy and increase our stewardship of the natural environment. In the submitted report, we provide a summary report on the status, opportunities, and challenges of four major topics covered by this workshop: (1) redox flow batteries for long duration energy storage, (2) Li metal batteries, (3) cathode materials, and (4) multi-valent batteries. 


Last Modified: 04/21/2023
Modified by: Tianbiao Liu
